1.  New Kid, New Problems

“You new in school?”

I get that a lot. It makes me sick.

“I am new,” I say. “What about it?”

“You have money?” the kid says.

The kid is not like a kid. He is big. Big. And I do have money. I have the money I need for a new CD. But I do not say that to the kid.

“Sorry, I am out,” I say.

“OK, kid,” he says. “No problem.” He walks on by. Then I see him stop.

“I do not like new kids,” he says. “I do not like you.”

“What can I say? I am sorry,” I say.

“Jake does not like people,” Tom says. “But I do.”

“What you can do,” the kid says, “is have money on you. I do not like you, but I do like money. Do you get it?” he says. Then he walks off.

People walk by in the school halls and see me and see the kid walk off. I want to hide. Then the next kid walks by me. He stops.

“What did you do to make Jake not like you?” he says.

“I am a new kid, and he does not like new kids,” I say.

“Jake does not like people,” the kid says. “But I do. I am Tom.”

“I am Dan,” I say. It makes me happy that Tom talks to me. I did not want to go to a new school, but my dad says I have to. He has a new job.

“What is it with that kid, Tom?” I say. “What is his problem?”

“Jake is like that,” Tom says. “He is a problem for a lot of people. He is a big kid and does what he wants.”

“A kid that big can do what he wants!” I kid about Jake.

Then Tom walks out of the school with me.

“Jake can be a problem,” Tom says. “You have to find friends. Jake does not boss kids with friends.”

“Then what about you, Tom?” I say. “Are you my friend?”

He stops. “I have to think about it,” he says. “Jake does not like you. That is a problem to me.”

“Think about it, then,” I say.

“I need to be getting home,” Tom says to me. “See you.”

“OK, see you,” I say. Then I walk to my house.

I am on my own, I think.

New house, new school, new kid — new problems.

2.  A Friend Like Big Dog

“Did school go OK, Dan?” Dad says.

“A lot of friends and a lot of A’s, Dad,” I say. With a new job and a new boss, my dad has a lot to think about. He does not need to see that I am not happy.

“Big Dog!” I call out. “Big Dog, I am home!” Big Dog is my dog. He is “Big Dog” because he does not find big problems. Big problems find Big Dog. But Big Dog makes me happy. On a school day, he waits on me to get home. Then we play.

Grandma walks in. She is my dad’s mom. She has a back problem and cannot walk a lot. She is not happy. I am getting a drink. “Can I get you a drink, Grandma?” I say.

“No,” she says. “I can get it on my own. But you can get that sorry dog out of the house,” she says. “Can’t you see that I am sick?” Grandma does not like Big Dog.

Dad says, “Mom, Big Dog makes Dan happy, and Dan needs that.” Dad goes to Grandma. “Dan’s friends and his girl are back in D.C., Mom,” he goes on. “In our new home, Dan needs a friend. Can’t Big Dog be that friend?”

Grandma cannot talk. Then, “My friends are back in D.C.,” she says to my dad. “Did you think about that?”

Dad sees me. I see Dad. We did not think about that. Grandma? with friends? We did not think about her needs.

“Grandma,” I say. “Can’t Big Dog be your friend?”

I see that Grandma needs a friend, too. Big Dog walks up to Grandma. He goes by her to wait. Then Grandma says, “Big Dog, I see that we need to be friends. I can’t have my friends in D.C., but I can make friends with you.” Big Dog is happy. I see that Grandma is happy, and that makes Dad and me happy.

3.  Who Is the Dog?

I do not see Tom at school the next day. I do see Jake. He is in the hall with the coach and does not see me.

“Sorry, Coach,” Jake says. I see the coach is not happy. Coach says, “Do not say you are sorry, Jake. Say you are going to play the next game!” The coach walks off. He is not happy. Then Jake sees me in the hall.

“What do you want, New Kid?” Jake says. “You waiting on me? You want problems?”

No, I do not want problems, I think. I want to hide! I walk on, but Jake stops me. “You think Coach is big?” Jake says. “I am bigger. He needs me. He needs me to make the big play in the game.”

“OK, Jake,” I say. “You are the big player. You can out-coach the coach. Can I go?”

“No, you cannot go,” Jake says. “What did you talk about with Tom, New Kid? Does he say I am a problem?” Jake says. He walks up to me. “I am a problem, kid,” he says. “I am your problem.”

“I do not want problems!” I say, but what to do? I can’t go! I can’t hide! What is Jake going to do to me? Then Jake hits me! He hits me, and I can’t stop it! I think I am going to get sick, sick, sick. Then, in the hall, a kid says, “Back off, Jake.”

Jake stops. “Tom!” he says. “What do you want? Are you going to back the new kid?”

I can see that Tom is thinking. “I am going to back him, Jake. I back my friends.”

Jake is not happy. He is not happy that Tom is going to be my friend. He walks off, but I can see that Jake will find me. “See you, New Kid,” he says.

“You OK, Dan?” Tom says.

“I am OK,” I say. “I think. Are you OK being my friend?”

“You need a friend,” Tom says. “I am going to back you.”

The coach walks in the hall. He sees Jake going. He sees us. “What is going on here?” the coach says.

“We are OK,” Tom says. “But Jake’s not happy with Dan.”

“Dan?” the coach says. “Dan, the new kid?”

“That is me,” I say. Being new makes me sick.

“I do not see what is going on with Jake,” the coach says. “He does not make the games. He makes problems.” Coach walks off. “I do not get it,” he says.

“He does not get it,” Tom talks like the coach.

“Get what?” I say.

Tom kids, “That Jake is a dog.”

4.  Lost Fire, But Not the Girl

I am about to walk home. Tom says to me, “School is out. What are you going to do today, Dan?”

“I am going home to get my money,” I say.

“Money?” Tom says.

“I am going to Boss CD,” I say. “I want the new Lost Fire CD, and my money is at home.” We stop walking. “Want to go with me?” I say.

“OK,” Tom says. “I can go to Boss CD.” It is new, like me. He and I walk on.

“What was D.C. like?” Tom says to me. “Do you have a girl?”

“No,” I say. “She is in D.C. I think about her a little, but that was D.C. That was then,” I say. “What about you, Tom? Do you have a girl?”

“Not today,” he kids me.

We get to my house. Big Dog is waiting for me out back, by Grandma. He is happy I am home. Grandma and Big Dog play.

“Big Dog, Grandma, that is Tom,” I say. “Tom, that is my grandma and my dog, Big Dog.”

Big Dog goes to Tom, and Tom plays with Big Dog. “My mom does not want me to have a dog, but I want to,” he says. Big Dog likes Tom. Tom sees that.

“He likes you,” I say. “You and Big Dog can be friends.”

“Can we, Big Dog?” Tom says. That makes Tom happy. Big Dog and Tom play, and I go to get my money.

“Grandma, we are going to Boss CD,” I say when I walk back out. “I have the car.”

“OK,” says Grandma. She goes in the house.

“What about Big Dog?” Tom says. “Can he go?”

“You want to go, Big Dog?” I say. He does. Big Dog gets a drink and is off to the car.

“Next stop, Boss CD!” I say to Tom and Big Dog.

Tom finds Boss CD with me, and we get out next to it. I stop when I see that a dog cannot go in.

Big Dog waits by the car, and we walk in. I go to the back. I see a lot of CDs, but not the new Lost Fire CD. Does Boss CD not have it? Wait. I see it. The girl next to me sees it, too, and I see her! I think about it and back off. She can have the Lost Fire CD. I want to talk to the girl!

5.  Dan and Kay Day

“Do you want the Lost Fire CD?” the girl says.

What CD? I think. The girl is the bigger hit with me! She goes to my new school. I see her in the halls.

“I do want it,” I say, “but you can have it.”

“No kidding?” she says.

“No kidding,” I say.

She is about to say who she is, but Tom walks back to us. “Kay!” he says. “What are you getting at Boss CD?”

“The new Lost Fire CD, Tom,” she says, “but I think your friend wanted it.”

Tom sees me. “Kay, that is Dan,” he says. “Dan, that is Kay. She goes to school with you and me.”

“I’m the new kid.” I say it so she does not have to. “I see you at school in the halls.”

“And I see you,” she says. Hmmm, I think.

“You can have the CD, Kay,” I say. “I want you to have it.”

She is happy, I can tell. But is she happy with me, or with the CD?

Tom, Kay, and I talk a little in Boss CD. She is a friend of Tom’s. I think I do not want her to be my friend. I think I want her to be my girl.

“Are you going to the game on Saturday?” Kay says.

“I am,” says Tom. “What about you, Dan?” Kay waits on me to say.

“Are you going, Kay?” I say. I wait.

“I want to go,” she says.

“Want to go with me, then?” I say.

Kay says she wants to go to the game with me. I am happy. I lost the CD, but I am getting the girl!

“Dan,” kids Tom, “I can go with you and Kay—that is, if you want me to. I back my friends.”

“You can back off,” I kid Tom back.

“I have to get going,” Kay says. “My sister is sick, and my mom’s waiting. But Saturday is OK,” she says. “I can’t wait!”

Kay walks out of Boss CD. Tom and I are about to go, but then a girl calls out. It is Kay! She needs Tom and me! What is going on?

“Big Dog!” Dan calls out. “Big Dog, get back!”

6.  Go, Big Dog, Go!

“Get back!” Kay calls out. “Dog, get back!”

“What the—?” Tom says, going out of Boss CD.

I see Kay. I see her call out. Then I see the truck! A big, big truck! It is going to hit a dog. It is going to hit—my dog!

“Big Dog!” I call out. “Big Dog, get back!”

Big Dog sees me. He stops to see what I want. “Do not stop!” I call out. “Go, Big Dog, go!”

“RRRRRRRRRRRRRR,” goes the truck. It can’t stop!

“Hide, Big Dog!” we call.

But the truck goes on! Big Dog sees it, but he does not go! Then the big truck does stop, but I think it hits my dog! It hits Big Dog!

What do I do? What can I do? Kay, Tom, and I want to go to Big Dog. But people say we can’t. “There are a lot of cars!” people say. “You have to wait!”

“I need to go to Big Dog!” I say. “I have to get to my dog!”

“Big Dog!” I call out. But the truck is by him, and I cannot see.

“Back off!” I say to the people. “I have to go to my dog!” But when I am going to Big Dog, the truck makes off. What is going on? No truck, no dog! “Big Dog!” I call. “Big Dog, it is me, Dan!”

Kay walks out to me. “What about your dog?” she says. “Is he OK?”

“I do not see the truck or Big Dog,” I say.

Then Tom walks to us. “Dan, I think the people in that truck are drinking.”

“You do?” I say. “You think a drinker hit my dog?” That does not make me happy. The people are drinking and hit my dog!

What to do? I think.

“I have to find Big Dog,” I say. “That is that. I have to find my dog.”

“Not on your own,” Tom says. “You need your friends. I want to go with you to find Big Dog.”

Kay says to me, “Dan, do you want me to find Big Dog with you? He is hit. He can have problems. He can be sick.”

“You think?” I say. I am not happy.

“I am going to call my mom,” says Kay. “I want to go with you to find your dog,” she says. “Then I can go to my sister.”

“OK,” I say. “Tom, you go talk to the people. Kay, you call your mom. Then go back by the cars.” I see a house next to Boss CD. A house, then a big lot, then a bigger house. “I am going to go by that lot,” I say. “I am going in back of the houses to find Big Dog.”

Tom, Kay, and I call and call Big Dog. Is he going to be OK?

7.  Waiting at 5th

I walk to the lot, but Big Dog is not in it or by it. I call and call Big Dog’s name. “Big Dog!” I say. “It is me, Dan!” But he is not in the lot. I go to the house next to the lot and call Big Dog. I go to the bigger house in back of the lot to see if Big Dog is by it. “Big Dog!” I call out. I do not see him. I go back to Tom and Kay, but I am sick about the truck hitting my dog.

Kay says, “Do you think that Big Dog is OK, but wants to hide?”

“No,” I say. “He does not hide.”

“Did you go in back of Boss CD?” Tom says to me.

“Dan did not,” Kay says to Tom, “but I did. No Big Dog.” Then Kay says to me, “How about the house by the lot, Dan?”

“I hit that,” I say. “No Big Dog.”

“I want to find Big Dog,” Kay says, “but I need to go home. My mom and sister are waiting.”

“That is OK,” I say. “I have to get Tom home.”

Kay goes off to her house, and Tom and I get in the car. When we get to Tom’s house, he gets out. He is going in the house, but then he walks back. “Dan,” he says, “Big Dog is lost, but I think he can find his home. He can find his home on his own.”

That makes me happy. Big Dog can get home on his own. Tom walks in his house, and I get going. Big Dog, I think, did you go home?

I stop the car at my house. Dad is out back. “Dad,” I say, “is Big Dog with you?”

“No, Dan, he is not,” Dad says.

“Did he get home?” I say. “Is he in the house?”

“No, Dan,” Dad says. “Grandma says he is with you! What is going on?”

“Big Dog is lost, Dad!” I say to him. “A truck hit him by Boss CD, and I can’t find him!”

Dad is sick for me. “I am sorry, Dan,” he says. “We have to do what we can, then wait.” He and I get in the car and go back to Boss CD. We call and call Big Dog. We say to people, “Did you see a dog?” But we cannot find Big Dog. When Dad gets in the car to go home, I say I am going to walk. I need to think.

I walk and walk. I think and think. I wait at 5th, with cars and trucks going by. Wait! What is that? It is the truck! It is the truck that hit Big Dog!

“Stop!” I call out. “Stop!” But the truck goes on. I am sick. What to do? I walk home, thinking out my problems. When I can see my house, I see that Dad and Grandma are out. And I see—what is that? What does my dad have?

“Big Dog!” I call out. “Dad, you have Big Dog!”

8.  No Friend, a Drinker

“You are home, Big Dog!” I say, going to get my friend. “You did hide!”

“No, Dan,” Dad says, “Big Dog did not hide. Grandma says a big truck did stop here with Big Dog. She says she did not see into the truck, but my money says that the friend in the truck wanted Big Dog home with you.”

“That is no friend,” I say. “He hit Big Dog.” I go to my grandma. “What did he say, Grandma?”

“I am sorry, Dan,” Grandma says, “but he did not talk to me. The people in the truck did not wait to talk.”

Dad walks to me. “Dan,” he says, “I see that you wanted to talk to the people in the truck, and I am sorry that you cannot.” He goes on, “But Big Dog is home. He is OK. The truck cannot have hit him.”

I go into the house and call Tom to say that Big Dog is home and OK. Then I call Kay.

“Big Dog is home?” Kay says. “I am happy for you, Dan! See, Big Dog can find his own way home!”

“But I don’t get it,” I say. “The truck that hit Big Dog is the truck that gets him home?”

“You have to be happy about that, Dan,” she says. “Big Dog is home, and he is OK.”

“I am happy, Kay. I am happy about a lot.”

“Is Saturday OK, then?” she says. “Am I going to the game with you?”

“Are you kidding?” I say. “I can’t wait! The game is at 7:30. Is 7:00 OK to get you?”

“You are on!” Kay says. “And, Dan?”

“Yes?”

“I can’t wait. See you then.”

9.  Back to Jake

At school the next day, I am happy. I am thinking about going to the game with Kay. I am thinking about Big Dog. Like I say, Big Dog does not find big problems. Big problems find Big Dog! But he is home and OK, and I am happy. That is what I am thinking about, walking to the PE hall.

But then I see Jake. Does Jake see me? Am I like Big Dog? Are problems going to find me? Oooooooo. I am like Big Dog. Jake sees me. And I am in the hall, waiting like a kid who likes problems! Think, Dan. Think! I back into the big school hall, and who do I back into but Tom!

“Sorry,” I say.

“What is going on, my friend?” Tom says, happy. Then he sees Jake.

“Jake, get off it,” Tom says. “Stop it with Dan! He’s OK. You are the problem.”

Jake sees me, and he sees Tom. He wants to talk. But then he says, “You think I am a problem? Is that it?”

“That’s it,” Tom says.

“That’s OK with me, then,” Jake says. “Be like that.” He walks off.

I want to stop him. I think about it. I do not like it when people do not like me. I think, Can’t we be friends? But Jake goes on into the PE hall, and I do not say what I am thinking.

Kay walks by us. “Dan? Tom? You OK?” she says.

Then I do not think about Jake. Kay’s with me. I think about her, and I think about the game the next day.

“We’re OK,” I say. “Can I walk you to PE?”

“I like that,” Kay says. “I like that a lot.”

“Hmmm. See you,” Tom says and backs off. That is a friend. Backs you and backs off when you need him to. Kay and I walk to PE.

“I was thinking,” Kay says, walking. “Tom says Jake does not like you.”

“That is Jake’s problem,” I say. “But I do like you, and that is no problem.” I do not want to talk about a kid like Jake with Kay.

“And I like you, Dan,” says Kay, “but think about it. Jake has a truck. He has a truck, and he does not like you.” She goes on. “Do you think that Jake hit Big Dog with his truck?”

I stop. “Did you say Jake has a truck?” I say.

“He does,” says Kay. “A big one, like the truck that hit Big Dog.”

A fire is going on in me. If Jake hit my dog, then he has a big problem, and his problem is me!

10.  The Big Game

I have to go on to PE, and I do not see Jake that day. But I think about him. Kay says he has a truck. When I see him next, he needs to do a little talking to me!

The next day is Saturday, and I do not want to think about Jake. Dad and Grandma are happy that I have a new friend and a new girl. Dad sees that I like the school by our new home a lot, and that makes him happy.

It is like the day walks by, without getting to the game. Then it is 7:00. I get to go see Kay.

When I get to her house, Kay’s dad goes to get her. “Dan,” she says, “this is my dad. Dad, this is Dan.” Kay’s dad says to be home by 11:30, and we say, “OK.” Then we are off.

“Dan,” Kay says, “this is my Dad.”

“It is a big game at our school,” says Kay when we get in the car. “I am happy I am going with you.”

When we get to the game, I get a drink for Kay. We wait for Tom and his friend, and I see that the coach is talking to Jake. Kay, Tom, his friend, and I go in to see the game. It is big. A lot of people want to see who can make the hits. By 9:30, it is 7-7, and we need 1 more big hit to get the players home. Jake is hitting next. Can the kid who can out-coach the coach make the big hit? Can he?

Coach is calling out to Jake. Jake walks back to the coach. Coach talks to Jake. Then Jake goes back to hit. Jake sees me, and it is like he needs a friend. I think about it. Then I call out, “Go on, Jake. You can do it!”

And Jake does do it! He fires a hit that gets 3 players home, and the game is his! People are happy, the coach is happy, and I am happy. Kay and I are walking out to my car when I see Jake. He is not with the coach. He is not with the players. It is me. He wants to get me. Can we get to the car?

“Dan!” Jake calls out. “Dan, I want to talk to you, kid!”

11.  No Friends, Big Problems

I stop. “Kay, you can get in the car,” I say to her.

“But, Dan—”

“Get in the car, Kay,” I say. “Jake wants to talk to me, and I want to talk to him.”

I get Kay into the car, and I see that Jake is waiting. I go back to him. “What do you want, Jake?” I say.

People go off to cars, and we wait. And wait. He wanted to talk, but it is like he can’t.

“What!” I say. “What do you want?”

“About your dog—”

“About my dog?” I say. “Then, it is your truck that hit Big Dog.” I am on fire!

“It is my truck, Dan,” he says, “but my dad hit your dog.”

“Go on,” I say.

“See, my dad has a drinking problem,” Jake says. “He drinks a lot. I do not like him to get in my truck drinking, but he is my dad. I can’t stop him.”

“And?” I say.

“We are going to the school to get what I need in the game on Saturday, and my dad is drinking. The truck hits your dog, and my dad stops.” Jake goes on. “I get the dog in the truck with me to see if he is OK, and my dad goes on. That,” says Jake, “is when I see that he is your dog, Big Dog.”

It is like Jake does not have a friend. He walks back to his truck, and I walk with him.

“And you get him to my house?” I say.

“That is about it,” says Jake. “But I am sorry.”

I think a little.

“Your dad hit Big Dog,” I say, “not you. And Big Dog is OK.”

“I am happy about that,” Jake says.

I stop. “Is your dad’s drinking what makes you hit the kids at school?” I say.

Jake stops. He finds he can talk about his dad with me. “I do not like friends to find out about my dad’s drinking,” Jake says. “That is it. No friends, no problems.”

12.  Big Friends, No Problem!

“But, Jake,” I say, “the problem is not your friends. It is your dad’s drinking.”

“You do not see,” Jake says. “I can’t have friends. Who wants a friend with problems?”

“All kids have problems, Jake,” I say. “Big and little. Your dad’s is a big problem, and your friends can back you at school and at home.”

“Like who?” Jake says. He cannot see that people can like him with a dad like his who drinks.

“Like me,” I say.

“No kidding?” Jake says.

“No kidding. Like me,” I say.

“And like me,” calls Kay, walking to Jake and me. “I am sorry, but I wanted to see that Dan is OK.”

“I am OK,” I say, “and Jake is OK. We are friends.”

Tom walks up next. “What is going on?” he says.

“We are OK,” I say. “We are talking about friends.”

“Then I am in,” Tom says. Jake is happy.

Jake gets in his truck. Tom goes back to his girl, and Kay and I go back to my car.

“Talk about a Saturday!” I say, getting into the car. “I get a new girl, a big school game, and a new friend!”

“And Big Dog is back,” says Kay. “It is a big day!”

“But I need to get you home, Kay,” I say. “Your dad says he wants you back by 11:30.”

When we get to her house, Kay gets out of the car. “What do you say you go in with me? I think I have a new CD you like,” she kids me.

“No,” I say. “What I like is you!”
